Ivanovich

body.div:
19 / 30 January 1709. – Letter from the Ambassador Extraordinary to Russia Charles Whitworth to the Under-Secretary of State George Tilson regarding the language of adressing to Tsar Peter I and his officials and difficulty and expense of providing mourning attireTNA Kew, Russia, no. SP 91-6, f. 19-19v. Copy.
Mosco 19/30 Jan. 1708/9
Now I am the most indebted for your oblidging Correspondence. I find myself in the least condition to pay, having been so taken up with writing to this Court in disposition, visits & other accidents, that I have only time to acknowledge the bare dates, the last whereof are the 12th & 16th Nov. by my letters to Mr. Secretary wherein you will decipher some lines you will find how the dispute sounds about the Ambassr. The language I write into this Court is pure High Dutch, the fashionable speech here understood by the Czar, Prince Menschikoff & extreamly well spoken by
[note in the lower edge:] Mr. Tilson
& writ[ten] by Mr. Scharfiroff who has the chief share in all foreign affairs. Latin has made little or no improvements since Ovids time. I have been three weeks in providing mourning & am not yet ready thou. I have not lost anytime, never was such a strange place. Shamoy gloves, shoes & mourning Swords are Heathen Greek & I believe the names were scarce ever heard before I enquired for them, in vain. I could none get cloath for my Servants, I was forced to give eight shillings a yard for that is not worth five, but however I had the advantage to be the first & the Danish Envoy will be forced to put his Servants into cloath of fourteen or sixteen shillings a yard no other black being left. I shall endeavour to make as good show as I can with my mourning, my countrymen willdo the same, and thou the Czar may go into black I scarce believe any of his Lords here will use that Ceremony things not being yet regulated as they ought; at least they did not for the late Empr[eror]. By the next post if it is possible I will do you more justice, & by answering y(our) favours more particularly will let you see the esteem I have for y(our) Correspondence being with great Sincerity D(ea}r Sir, y(our) most humble servantCWitworth
